_header: Hende in hall an ye will hear / Of elders that before us were
Note:
crit. text: Schleich (1901)
XSchleich, Gustav. Sir Ysumbras: Eine englische Romanze des 14 Jahrhunderts, im Aschluss an die vorarbeiten J. Zuupitza.
Palaestra 15. Berlin: Mayer & Müller, 1901, (804 lines).

BodAsh61.First Lines:
[H]ende in halle & ȝe schall hereof elders þat be
                    fforn vs wereThere lyues how þat dyde ledeI schall ȝow telle
                    A wonder case…
BodAsh61.Last Lines: …And to heuen yer saules wenteWhen yi dede were
BodAsh61.Editions:
Shuffleton,  George. 
             Ashmole 61: A Compilation of Popular Middle English Verse.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 2008: 39-59; 432-7; 599-600.

BodDou261.First Lines:
LOrdynges lysten and youe shall heareOf elders that before vs
                    weare…
BodDou261.Last Lines:
…By that he had hym armure dightAll that longed to a
                    knyght
BodDou261.Note: Mid-sixteenth-century transcript of an early print.
BodDou261.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth the hystorye of the valyaunte knyght Syr Isenbras (f.
                    1)
BodDou261.Editions:
Schleich,  Gustav,
                        ed.  
             Sir Ysumbras: Eine englische Romanze des 14 Jahrhunderts, im Aschluss
                an die vorarbeiten J. Zuupitza.
Palaestra
         15. Berlin: Mayer & Müller, 1901: (critical edition; 804 lines).

BodMal941.First Lines:
[That false S]ow[dan for to yelde][For the wo] that he hy[m
                    wrought][Syr Isenbr]as [al]one [vp stode][Ryght e]ger was he o[f
                    mode]…
BodMal941.Last Lines:
…[I shall thee make a knyg]ht[In a nonry they dyd hy]m
                    leue
BodMal941.Editions:
Zupitza,  Julius. 
             “Zum Sir Isumbras.” 
             Archiv für das Studium der neueren Sprachen und
                Literaturen
         88 (1891): 72-3: 72-3.

OxfUni142.Transcription:
All þat wyllyn þys romonse hereOf lordes þat be fore
                    ous wereand leued here yn ledeIhesu þat ys heuen kyngSo
                    grant ham all hys bessyng [sic]and heuene to here medeI woll
                    now tell of a knyȝtþat was herdy man and wytȝand
                    duȝty of hys dedehys name was syr IsambrasSo duȝty a
                    knyȝt as he wasleuand none in ledeþat myȝt with hym
                    with oute fayllIn tuement ne In baytayllto usten opno [sic] a
                    stedehe was a man of muchel strangWith schuldres brode and armus a
                    lang…
OxfUni142.Note:
Added to originally blank flyleaf at end of volume, by hand of s. xv; a
                    fragment, lines 1-17.
OxfUni142.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             “A Passage from Sir Isumbras.” 
             Englische Studien
         48 (1915): 329: 329.

CamGon175.First Lines:
Hende in halle & ȝe wole hereOff eldres þat be fore
                    vs were…
CamGon175.Last Lines: …Geue vs ay hys blessyngAnd schylde vs from care
CamGon175.Attributed Title:
Hic incipit de milite Ysumbras (p. 98b); Explicit
                    ser ysumbras (p. 107b)
CamGon175.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             “A Passage from Sir Isumbras.” 
             Englische Studien
         48 (1915): 329: 329.
Hudson,  Harriet,
                        ed.  
             Four Middle English
                    Romances: Sir Isumbras, Octavian, Sir Eglamour of Artois, Sir
                Tryamour.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 1996. 2nd ed.
            2006.

BlCottCalAII.First Lines:
God þat made both erþe & heueneAnd all þis
                    worlde in deyes seueneThat is full of myȝtheSende vs alle his
                    blessyngeLasse & more olde & ȝyngeAnd kepe vs day &
                    nyȝteI wyll ȝou tell of a knyȝte…
BlCottCalAII.Last Lines:
…Graunte vs all þy blessyngeffor now & euer
                    more
BlCottCalAII.Note:
With variant first stanza (6 lines) and this version in 6-line stanzas
                    aabccb; ends ‘Amen’ at end of last line and ‘Explicit’
                    beneath last line, f. 134rb.
BlCottCalAII.Attributed Title:
Isumbras (in upper margin, f. 13), and as RT on verso leaves thereafter);
                    Isumbras (f. 1, sixteenth-century list of contents)

NLS1931.First Lines:
Hynd in hall yf ye wyll hereOf elders þat be for hus
                    were…
NLS1931.Last Lines:
…he grant vs all his blessyngNow and euer more
                    Amen
NLS1931.Facsimiles:
Hardman,  Phillipa. 
             The Heege Manuscript: A Facsimile of National Library of Scotland MS
                Advocates 19.3.1.
         Leeds Texts and Monographs, n.s. 16. Leeds: School of English,
            2000.

GraysInn20.First Lines:
…we axy hem some [mete]ȝf we mouwe [any]
                    gete…
GraysInn20.Last Lines:
…[Sche] sayde lord by char[yte][A bowne þat þou wold
                    graunt me]Wiþoute [any] dwellyng…
GraysInn20.Note:
A single sheet bound in as flyleaf at the rear, foliated in pencil as
                    ‘228’, lines 226-330.
GraysInn20.Editions:
D’Evelyn,  Charlotte. 
             “The Gray’s Inn Fragment of Sir Ysumbras.” 
             Englische Studien
         52 (1918): 72-6: 73-6.

Lincoln91.First Lines:
Ihesu christ lorde of heuene kyngeGraunte vs alle his dere
                    blyssyngeAnd heuene vn to oure medeNow hende in haule & ȝe
                    wolde here…
Lincoln91.Last Lines:
…Praye we now to heuen es kyngehe gyffe vs alle his dere
                    blyssyngeNowe and euer mare Amen Amen Explicit sir
                    ysambrace
Lincoln91.Attributed Title: Here begynnes the romance off sir ysambrace (f. 109rb)
Lincoln91.Facsimiles:
Brewer,  Derek Stanley,  and  A. E. B. Owen.  
             “Introduction.” 
             The Thornton Manuscript (Lincoln Cathedral MS. 91).
         London: Scolar Press, 1975.
Lincoln91.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             The Thornton Romances: The Early English Metrical Romances of Perceval,
                Isumbras, Eglamour, and Degrevant.
Camden Society
         o.s. 30 (1844); repr. F.S. Ellis, Kelmscott Press, 1897: 88-120.
Ellis,  Frederick Startridge,
                        ed.  
             Sir Isumbras.
         Hammersmith: Kelmscott, 1897: (Halliwell text).

NapXIIIB29.First Lines:
[H]e þat made beþe hevyn & erthe& al þis
                    worlde in daies seuyn…
NapXIIIB29.Last Lines:
…our frend of vs shulle be Iirchouer londe y rede we
                    fare
NapXIIIB29.Editions:
Kölbing,  Eugen. 
             “Das Neapler Fragment von Sir Isumbras.” 
             Englische Studien
         3 (1880): 92-105, 273-334: 200-2.
Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.  
             Reliquiae Antiquae.
         2 vols. London: Smith, 1845: 2.67.
